utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
Tom, thanks very much for the call, and good luck finding parking spots for that semi rig.
Thank you, sir.
So long.
Let's turn now to - this is Mary(ph).
Mary's with us from Tempe, Arizona.
Hi.
Hi.
Yeah, I was just excited to hear that there is another parking enthusiast out there.
Parallel parking makes my day.
I will specifically like look for a parallel spot just to make my day a little better in the morning.
And last week I was parking in a particularly tight spot, and I was really proud of myself when I got in there.
And as I got out of the car, a man on the street turned to me and said, that was a beautiful park.
And it just made my life a whole lot better.

Of course, that's sort of like in New York if you go out for the evening, just say somebody's house for dinner, and you find a beautiful spot and you manage to get in it, then you realize you've sort of peaked for the day.
I mean, nothing at the dinner party could be possibly - could beat finding that spot.
So that's the problem of doing that early in the morning.

And do you find yourself then looking for the parking signage to find out when it might be required - you're not going to move that car again until you absolutely have to, until the alternate side of the street parking kicks in.
Yeah, I mean even if you have to walk all the way home.
Absolutely.
Yeah, the…
Or take a cab.
That's what New York parkers call good for tomorrow.
I've actually had the pleasure of parking in New York and finding that perfect spot, and I didn't move my car for a long time, a whole day, pretty much.
A whole day.
Mary, do you turn your nose up at a spot that has three feet to either side and wait for that spot where it's a challenge for you?
I do.
I like the challenge.
I look for those - I don't know what did you call it, bread-slicing spots?
I look for that.
I love it.
I love the challenge, parking - because it's one of the few things I think I'm really good at.
It's my talent.
Well that's exactly what I said in the piece.
That if I were asked what's your talent in the way that the Miss America contest uses the word, as in Miss West Virginia will now do her talent, I would say parallel parking.
Mary, it sounds like you could win any talent contest across the country.
All you need is a jury with an open mind and an open parking spot.
Sure.
Thanks very much for the call, Mary.
Thank you.
With this device, Calvin Trillin, where does the future lead?
Surely they will invent one that needs less than six-and-a-half feet of clearance space.
Well, I think that what they need is to move in another direction, and that is find - have a device that actually finds the spot.
I mean that can tell within a four or five-block area where there is some opening between cars that is not next to a fire hydrant or a driveway.
And so I think if they can combine this sort of tracking thing they already have in cars with the parking, then we're on our way.
And I have to hand it to Lexus for sort of being the pace-setter in this field.
I mean, it's what we would I think in five years we'll think of as sort of a primitive device.
I compared it in the piece to a cell phone that actually is used for making and receiving telephone calls, I mean something truly 19th century.
But that Lexus for the price of only $1,200 has shown the way on this.
And so I expect, you know, Mercedes to counter with one that will find a spot and maybe Infiniti to get one that will combine finding the spot and parking in it, and…
Calvin Trillin, I'm afraid we have to end it there.
The future's now.
Thanks so much for being with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Oh darn it, what did I need?
WEEKEND EDITION'S food commentator Bonny Wolf lives in the Capitol Hill section of Washington.
Her home is only a few steps away from the Eastern Market, a block-long, one-story brick building where you can buy fresh fruits, flowers, vegetables, fish, poultry, ice cream, even penny candy.
Okay.
Spinach.
Are we eating spinach now?
Are you still eating spinach?
(Unintelligible)
Inside the Watts Healthcare Corporation, a marble podium contains what looks like three oversized jewels.
Closer inspection reveals they're really chunks of melted glass from buildings that burned during the 1965 Watts riot.
The riots protested not only the pervasive police brutality of the time, but an appalling lack of vital services, including health care for the area's residents.
William Hobson is president and CEO of Watts Healthcare, a private non-profit.
He was happy to hear Governor Schwarzenegger's intention to offer health insurance to all Californians, regardless of citizenship status.
That's very good news to programs like ours.
We provide services to anyone that presents at our program for health care.
We don't have the wherewithal to do any type of citizenship verification.
So what we would like to be able to do is to be able to provide services to all individuals.
Watts Healthcare served 22,000 people in 2005.
That's the last year statistics are available.
Patients came for family medicine, pediatric care, OB-GYN services, and for help fighting chronic diseases that are pervasive in poor communities like diabetes and hypertension.
Bill Hobson says most of his patients come from the more than half dozen sprawling housing projects that ring the center.
Over three-quarters of the center's families fall below federal poverty guidelines, which means that even simple things like basic prescriptions for chronic treatable diseases can be unaffordable.
We try to do what we can to provide pharmaceuticals for patients with really low incomes.
We can never do enough.
That's a challenge the governor will have to address in order to make health care reform meaningful for the people Watts Healthcare serves.
And, says Bill Hobson, some of his patients already have insurance through their jobs, but using it is too expensive.
They may have a 1,000, $1,500, or $2,000 deductible per family member.
So, in effect, at the incomes - if they work in minimum wage or near minimum wage - they're in effect uninsured, even though they have insurance.
Yet, another challenge for the governor and the state legislature, as they begin to construct a practical health care model for California that may eventually work for the rest of the country.
Karen Grigsby Bates, NPR News.
Last year Hurricane Katrina killed more than 1,000 people and left hundreds of thousands without jobs or homes.
NPR News today begins a series, Katrina: Where Did the Money Go?
And over the next three days we'll be following that question.
We begin this morning with some stories about the personal financial toll.
DAY TO DAY has followed the story of one family, the Smith's from New Orleans.
The Smith's now live in Texas.
But they find that putting their lives back together means returning to their hometown again and again.
Joshua Levs reports.
Selwyn Smith is sitting in a rented SUV in the stifling heat outside a small rundown housing project in New Orleans.
There's a hidden section aid office here.
Sometimes you can get in and get right out and sometimes you may have to sit here for a couple hours.
People on government assistance come here to get lists of available homes to rent.
And people looking to rent their homes out can sign up for an inspection.
Chiquita, Selwyn's wife, is waiting inside to book one.
They can't call or sign up online.
They have to drive here and wait.
After about an hour, Chiquita comes back.
So we good?
We got another appointment?
They gonna call (unintelligible)
They'll probably call me.
The Smiths made the 10 hour drive yesterday from their home in McKinney, Texas, just outside Dallas.
It's Selwyn's seventh trip back to New Orleans.
